pullRequest.body:
This module defines orientable manifolds. [This](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Orientable.20Surface) Zulip topic is related.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [af0d8a021e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16239/commits/af0d8a021e6f4542de979629bbd5341525068ae9)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
|<details><summary>4 files</summary> `Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.Instances.Real` `Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.PoincareConjecture` `Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.WhitneyEmbedding` `Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.Instances.Sphere`</details>|1|
| `Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.Orientable`|1600|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Icc_orientable_manifold`
`+ OrientableManifold`
`+ OrientableSmoothManifold`
`+ OrientationPreserving`
`+ OrientationPreserving.differentiableAt`
`+ OrientationReversing`
`+ OrientationReversing.differentiableAt`
`+ contDiffOrientationPreservingGroupoid`
`+ instance : OrientableManifold (ùì°‚àÇ 1) (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1) := by infer_instance`
`+ instance {E : Type*} [NormedAddCommGroup E] [NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù E]`
`+ ofSet_mem_orientationPreservingGroupoid`
`+ orientableManifold_of_zero_dim`
`+ orientationPreservingGroupoid`
`+ orientationPreservingPregroupoid`
`+ orientationPreserving_comp`
`+ orientationPreserving_comp_orientationReversing`
`+ orientationPreserving_id`
`+ orientationPreserving_of_zero_dim`
`+ orientationReversing_comp`
`+ orientationReversing_comp_orientationPreserving`
`+ symm_trans_mem_orientationPreservingGroupoid`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Another thought just came to my mind: there is a notion of orientability of *topological* manifolds, using local orientations. (This is not an issue for surfaces, as topological and smooth manifolds are the same in dimension less than four.)
Having this definition is useful now, but it's a definition only for differentiable manifolds. Can you add a comment clarifying this assumption?
Another interesting follow-up lemma could be to define orientation-preserving (or reversing) map between smooth manifolds. Up to you if you'd like to do this!

Thanks! Let's have another pair of eyes on this.
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

I looks like this only deals with the case of manifolds without boundary. I think this approach to orientability can be made to work for boundary (though it's a bit fiddly).

What if I wanted to use this definition state Stokes's theorem?

For the sake of a concrete goal, I'd be much happier merging something that included an instance of orientability for `(Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1)`.

Thanks for this PR, I am excited to see somebody work on it! I have one comment, which could simplify your definition and proofs, and one follow-up request.

Right now, this is just a definition, without any API. Do you mind adding some lemmas about this definition, such as
- the identity is orientation-preserving
- the composition of two orientation-preserving maps is orientation-preserving
- (optional) define orientation-reversing maps; show that (over a connected set), each diffeomorphism is either orientation-preserving or reversing
- (optional) the composition of or.-preserving and -reversing is orientation-reversing; composing two orientation-reversing maps yields something orientation-preserving

Another future possibility (perhaps not for this PR) could be to define the groupoid of smooth orientation-preserving manifolds. You need not do all of these! But the first two items above would be nice, to confirm this definition is usable.

Thanks for addressing these comments so quickly! I think this PR is converging quickly. I took a quick look; all comments I have are pretty minor. (I didn't look at the proofs in detail yet.) It's time for dinner now; I'll try my best to return to this afterwards.
Here are my remaining comments for today.
Wow, you're quick! I took a close look at the proofs and have a few golfs to suggest. Should be quick to address. After that, it's probably ready to be maintainer merged.
style comment: I would write this one one line

Also: I think you can remove the differentiability requirement, as `fderiv` has junk value `0` whenever the map is not differentiable. (Perhaps add a comment to that effect, if you find one helpful.)
That ought to simplify later proof, right?

I've considered doing that, and it turns out that I will need to add another condition to get differentiability from the positivity of `fderiv`, one possible condition to obtain that is `FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù H ‚â† 0` (cf. `LinearMap.det_zero`). Since I need to add a condition anyways, I decided to go with the one that sounded to me closer to spoken mathematics. Do you think that the `FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù H ‚â† 0` condition is better in our case?
This line and the next ones look like they could use dot notation, right?
Dot notation works for the next lines, but not for this one (the `have` proof terms).

Let's be more precise: "a map between normed spaces ..."
(This notion also exists for maps between oriented manifolds, which this PR is a step towards.)
Can you mention the corresponding declarations for orientation-reversing as well?

```suggestion
  admits an orientation.
Similarly as above, can you clarify this to "A map between normed spaces"? Same comment for the other declarations below.

If I understand Lean's convention (0^0 = 1) correctly, this means 0-dimensional manifolds are orientable. (This is mathematically correct: these are simply points; an orientation of a zero-manifold simply assigns each point a value $$\pm 1$$.)
Can you add a lemma stating this, that `H` being 0-dimensional implies f is orientation-preserving?

Three small comments: all of them also apply to the other lemmas below.
- I think you don't need the `Nontrivial H` assumption: if `H` is zero-dimensional, `f` is always differentiable. I think mathlib has this already; ping me if you get stuck finding it!
- By default, I would put the `x` "left of the colon", i.e. write "(x : s) : DifferentiableAt \R f x" instead. Do you have a reason to do this differently?
- In terms of naming, I'd write "OrientationPreserving.differentiableAt".

Thank you for pointing these out! Regarding point two: instead of writing `(x : s)`, I decided to look at similar lemmas in mathlib and imitate how it is done there (e.g. `DifferentiableWithinAt.differentiableAt`).
`orientationReversing_comp_orientationPreserving`, please - thanks!
Can you add the corollary that 0-dimensional manifolds are always orientable?
IIUC, this PR already handles the 0-dimensional case (and correctly). Instead, I would extend this TODO slightly differently: I'll leave this blank for now and try to return here after dinner.

So, here's an initial list of what I'd write.
- try to generalise this discussion to any non-trivially normed field
- on a given connected set, a diffeomorphism is either orientation-preserving or orientation-reversing
- a normed space (with the trivial model) is orientable
- the n-sphere is orientable
- products of orientable manifolds are orientable

- define orientations of a smooth manifold, and show that a manifold is orientable if and only if it admits an orientation
- define orientation-preserving and reserving maps between manifolds
Can you also add a "main results" section, please? It could e.g. contain the results about 0-dimensionality or about composition of orientation-preserving and -reserving maps.

Here's a slightly longer version, if you prefer:
```This file defines orientable manifolds: a differentiable manifold is orientable if and only if it admits an orientable atlas, i.e. an atlas whose transition functions have positive Jacobian.```

Thinking about it more, it would be nice to mention the choice of definition also. What do you think about this (rewrapping lines as needed)?
```suggestion
## Implementation notes

The current definitions work for differentiable manifolds (and is simpler to define this way).
For topological manifolds, orientability can be defined using *local* orientations
(which mathlib cannot even state yet, as there is no e.g. singular homology).
In the future, it would be nice to generalise these definitions to allow for topological manifolds also, and relate them to the current definition.

Hm, I'd need to think if this does what we'd want: this definition asks for "M has a smooth atlas, and M has an orientable atlas" - whereas the obviously correct definition would be "M has a smooth orientable atlas" (i.e., one atlas which is both smooth and orientable).
What do you think about mentioning that 0-dimensional manifolds are always orientable?

I tried this and got stuck somewhere; let's tone down the wording.
```suggestion
- Generalize this discussion to other fields; it certainly makes sense over ‚Ñö

```suggestion
- Define orientation preserving and reversing maps between manifolds.

You can golf this proof, using `LinearMap.det_eq_one_of_finrank_eq_zero.`
(I am not sure which way of saying "is zero-dimension" is the best one; a maintainer can certainly weigh in on this.)
```
lemma orientationPreserving_of_zero_dim (f : H ‚Üí H) (s : Set H)
    (h : FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù H = 0) : OrientationPreserving f s := by
  intro _ _
  simp [LinearMap.det_eq_one_of_finrank_eq_zero h]
```

I personally prefer the comment on top of the section name. I wonder if the current behaviour is also incidental due to the port. Not a strong opinion, in any way.
```
 /-! ### Orientable manifolds -/

section OrientableManifold
```

```suggestion
  compatible := fun _ _ ‚Ü¶

The first case can be golfed a little, to
```
apply ((s.subsingleton_of_subsingleton).differentiableOn _ hs).differentiableAt
exact mem_nhds_discrete.mpr hs
```
I would argue this is mathematically "trivial", hence fine.

In general, `unfold` is a bit of a "code smell": a sign that something is not ideal (such as, a missing simple lemma about the definition to use). In this case, you can just `rw` by the definition instead.
```suggestion
  ¬∑ rw [OrientationPreserving] at h
Please also `rw` here.

Here is a golf of the last three lines ("unfold" to "exact").
- avoiding `unfold` in favour of `rw`
- in fact, `simp` can also be used (which makes this even shorter)
- in the last step, `simp` followed by `exact` can often be converged to `simpa [...] using`: I think that is more readable here.
Overall, I'd suggest
```
simpa [ContinuousLinearMap.det] using mul_pos (hg (f x) hxv) (hf x hxu)
```

Please make the same change to the other three lemmas below.
You *could* extract that groupoid and give it a name. Up to you!
Thanks for the suggestions! I wasn't able to extract the groupoid cleanly, I think it is okay without extraction, what do you think?
I think this is fine as-is; if necessary, it can always be extracted later.

pullRequest.title: feat(Geometry/Manifold): orientable manifolds
